Modals

  • Default
  • Alternative
  • On Boarding
  • JS Documentation
  • HTML Documentation

Default

This modal can come in two different sizes: default, that's 600px width; and large, that's 980px width.

Currently is not possible to have small or reduced sizes for this dialog.

Alternative

This type of modal differ from default modal in two main things: it's content is center aligned, header and footer does not have any border to visually split them from body content.

It can be used in two different modes (or cases):

Commonly used on dialogs to delete an element or confirm an action. There are some cases when are accompanied by a footer image.

This modal can come in four different sizes: default, that's 600px width; reduced, that's 500px width; small, that's 400px width; and large, that's 980px width.

This kind of dialog is commonly used for integrations settings or in cases where we need to highlight the image of the product we're editing.

On Boarding

On boarding modal has two modes: forward tour, that's a modal that cannot go back to previous step; and navigation tour, that's a modal that will allow users to go back to previous step with an arrow located at top left of the modal content.

This modal comes in a unique size by default 500px width and does not support extra classes for size changes.

JS Documentation

If you are using individual js components, dialog.js and a11y-dialog.js are both required.

Dialogs are streamlined, but flexible, dialog prompts with the minimum required functionality.

We use the library A11y-Dialog to make sure they're accessible as possible.

Any dialogs with the class sui-dialog will be instantiated and stored in SUI.dialogs with their id. You will be able to call methods on these instances e.g. SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].hide() will hide the corresponding dialog with the id my-accessible-dialog.

Javascript Instantiation 
// Get the dialog element (with the accessor method you want)
const el = document.getElementById('my-accessible-dialog');

// Instantiate a new A11yDialog module
const dialog = new A11yDialog(el);
DOM API

The following button will open the dialog with the my-accessible-dialog id when interacted with.

<button type="button" data-a11y-dialog-show="my-accessible-dialog">Open the dialog</button>

The following button will hide the dialog with the my-accessible-dialog id when interacted with.

<button type="button" data-a11y-dialog-hide>Close the dialog</button>
JS API

Regarding the JS API, it simply consists on show() and hide() methods on the dialog instance.

// Show the dialog
dialog.show();

// Hide the dialog
dialog.hide();
Changing Animations

See example below changing the animation to fade instead of bounce for the modal with id my-accessible-dialog.

Note: You will have run this code after the dialog has been instantiated.

// Change animation on the show event
SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].on( 'show', function( dialogEl, event ) {
	var content = dialogEl.getElementsByClassName( 'sui-dialog-content' );
	content[0].className = 'sui-dialog-content sui-fade-in';
});

// Change animation on the hide event
SUI.dialogs['my-accessible-dialog'].on( 'hide', function( dialogEl, event ) {
	var content = dialogEl.getElementsByClassName( 'sui-dialog-content' );
	content[0].className = 'sui-dialog-content sui-fade-out';
});

HTML Documentation

Base Markup

All modals will share the same structure presented in the sample markup below this paragraph. This markup will be the base for everything and will only change content inside role="document" element, plus in some cases an additional class will be added next to sui-dialog to indicate what kind of modal you want.

<div
	tabindex="-1"
	id="unique-id"
	class="sui-dialog"
	aria-hidden="true"
>

	<!--
	ELEMENT: Overlay Mask

	NOTE: Add "data-a11y-dialog-hide" attribute if you want to hide the modal when clicking on mask,
		  or remove this attribute and control this action directly on your project.

		  Have in mind this will only hide the modal but not reset any actions performed by user,
		  like unselect all selected options.
	-->
	<div class="sui-dialog-overlay" data-a11y-dialog-hide></div>

	<!-- ELEMENT: Modal Content -->
	<div
		class="sui-dialog-content"
		aria-labelledby="title-unique-id"
		aria-describedby="description-unique-id"
		role="dialog"
	>

		<div role="document" class="sui-box"> ... </div>

	</div>

</div>
Modal Types

There are three types of dialogs: default, alternative and on boarding. These types come in different sizes and designs, but they all use sui-dialog as base class. To get alternative or on boarding types you must addition an extra class to it.

<!-- TYPE: Default -->
<div class="sui-dialog">...</div>

<!-- TYPE: Alternative
Simply add "sui-dialog-alt" extra class.
-->
<div class="sui-dialog sui-dialog-alt">...</div>

<!-- TYPE: On Boarding
Simply add "sui-dialog-onboard" extra class.
-->
<div class="sui-dialog sui-dialog-onboard">...</div>
Modal Sizes

Aside from default size, modals also come in three different sizes: small, reduced and large; but not all types of modals support it. To make sure the size is supported by the type of modal you want to use, we recommend you to review other sections of this page to preview samples.

<!--
SIZE: Small
Simply add "sui-dialog-sm" extra class.
-->
<div class="sui-dialog sui-dialog-sm">...</div>

<!--
SIZE: Reduced
Simply add "sui-dialog-reduced" extra class.
-->
<div class="sui-dialog sui-dialog-reduced">...</div>

<!--
SIZE: Large
Simply add "sui-dialog-lg" extra class.
-->
<div class="sui-dialog sui-dialog-lg">...</div>

    Ok so this is the first step in the experience. The user can close the modal to cancel the flow but the primary action is to proceed using the button. These will usually be user triggered actions like adding a new module.

    In the final step, we change the button back to blue to subconsciously highlight that it’s a final step. In this example the user is unable to go back and must proceed.

  • Basic Tour

    In this example, we allow the user to go back and forth between screens and provide basic controls. This is most likely how onboarding tutorials will be.

    Ok so this is the first step in the experience. The user can close the modal, or go to the previous screen via the buttons up top. The primary action is to proceed using the button. All of this works well on mobile too.
